passages.text: USA | Semiconductors
Conf. Wrap: Interconnect Hot, Broad Cycle Slowly Progressing, Memory Concerns

Our conference just wrapped up with roughly 100 companies in attendance. The tone was much better than last year, but it's the AI/Optical market where companies sounded the best. Analog names seeing improvements but the true upcycle seems more a 2026 story. Semi Cap sentiment still low and while we continue to get more client interest, there still seems to be more downside than upside next year. Sentiment was lowest in Memory given fears of eventual oversupply.

On the AI side, NVDA guidance was only in line but should see increasing strength as Blackwell ramps. Optical was the brightest area with LITE favored given a more incremental 800G/1.6T ramp vs COHR but both should see tailwinds. 200G/lane should also push more active cabling, which is a 2026 driver for both ACCs (MTSI and SMTC) and AECs (CRDO and ALAB). MTSI is one of our favorite names here given strong ramps in A&D and Telco and this DC opportunity layering on top. On the ASIC side, Trn2 builds seem unchanged (ALAB) and we will get more color from MRVL tomorrow.

The messaging from Analog names remained constructive but with seasonality swinging negative, the broader recovery is likely a 2026 story. In SPE, AMAT did seem to be more of an anomaly with others not pointing to China weakness. LRCX sounded very confident in its competitive position with drivers such as Moly but it's hard to avoid the Memory overhang for the group. Mobile seemed a bit lackluster with the Android market likely softer into the end of the year and not much excitement for the IP17. Finally, Memory is the area where investors were the most negative as there are fears that a Samsung HBM qualification (which the market is viewing as increasingly likely) would likely cause an oversupply and NAND fears circle around a softer demand profile pushing pricing lower. Please join our call to discuss our takeaways on Thursday 8/28 @ 10am ET.
Takeaways for each company are below.

- Announced membership in the Ultra Accelerator Link Consortium (UALink). NoC technology is already used to develop advanced high-bandwidth, low-latency HPC and AI accelerators, where UALink will support standards-based scale-up.- Future opportunities in Heterogenous chiplets (in infancy but starting to see project initiation - 3 chiplets from one and 2 chiplets from another).- China is stable - still getting orders from China but not at the level of prior years. Current level of bookings is stable.- FX headwinds from weakening USD as the majority of engineers operate outside of the US (30-40% of employees paid in EUR).

- 2025 Scorpio P Series sales primarily related to NVDA sales. Scorpio P for ASICs starts to be a larger opportunity in 2026.- Trainium 2 will remain at the current content levels, with upside coming from the next platform.- Multiple customers driving X series demand in 2026 with UAL related Scorpio X in 2027 when the hardware is ready. Will include a full suite of products including switches, chiplets, retimed cables, etc.- SCM similar in size to the AEC business and outgrowing retimers. Gearboxes still relatively small.- Content opportunity in the hundreds of dollars but could rise to \(\) 1k+\(over time between the entire suite of products.- AEC revenue is all 400G speeds this year with 800G ramping next year.

- Significant opportunity in Robotics tied to Humanoid robots with demand in NA but also a lot of companies in China. Humanoid robots needed position sensors in every joint, also TMR, as well as power.- Company reiterated they have no seen evidence of pull-ins from China, still believe its mostly part shortages.- DC back to \(\) 6/7M\(revenue per quarter after troughing\) \leq \$1M\(per quarter. Believe they've worked through all the inventory in air cooling and have liquid cooling wins ramping later this year.-\) \ \(425\) content opportunity per AI rack vs. GP server opportunity of \(\) 150\$.- Japan auto production likely to be down 7-8% and ALGM not immune to weakness in that market but nothing structural.- Two wins for isolated gate drivers for relatively small volumes but still new products and plenty of runway for additional growth.

Non- linear demand in GAA based on broader fab readiness, not specifically based on TSMC fabs - with Samsung Taylor fab and Intel's Ohio fab creating moving pieces. Still very confident in share and expect 2026 to be a strong year for leading edge F/L.- Overshipped into China relative to production in 2023/2024 so need to digest. Don't believe there is any share loss to local players in China.

AMD- China opportunity sounds softer going forward with no real expectation it gets back to prior levels. Wrote down \(\) 800M\(in inventory but much of that was purchase commitments.- Expect there will be some China revenue in the quarter though with GM benefit likely in 4Q25 with potential that spills into 1Q26.- A few large hyperscalers are customers for MI355 with some announced and some coming. MI355x works great for inference and can do training but those decisions were made last year.- Currently offering 10 - 20k cluster training with MI355x but more likely to move to scale training with MI400 series and Helios rack scale solution in 2H26.- Engaged with multiple parties, both public and private, on UAL switching and noted only 1- 2% degradation of performance from UAL over Ethernet.

CAMT- China will remain strong - still not strong local competition - China could be around \(40\%\) this year and into next year.- \(30\%\) of the business in first year of introduction will be Hawk + Gen 5, rising to \(50 - 60\%\) next year. Positive contribution to the margin but small impact - could push to \(53\%\) if everything goes well.- Gaining share in Cowos with ASE and Amkor- Significant number of steps that need new tools for HBM 4, smaller microbumps to save on height.- Still relatively little competition from local players in China

COHR- Industry pricing from 800G to 1.6T likely up \(\sim 30\%\) with demand keeping pricing strong.- EMLs in shortage, ramping 4 inch InP fabs with 6in fab having been in the works for 18 months, beginning production this quarter. Fab turning on is step function change with many products.- Building significant InP capacity with the long term goal of selling externally.- Most transceiver wins are dual sourced and can increase insourcing with capacity ramp. Can pass on some savings from EML capacity to the customer to increase insourcing. 6in can reduce costs by \(\sim 60\%\)

GFS- Pricing in Auto is stable - don't see downward pressure. More pricing pressure in Mobile - few sockets are dual- sourced, trading share for revenue (one- off declines - ends up being margin accretive).- CapEx will be up next year with focus on AP, die to wafer bonding, which is not as intensive as building new fabs but overall spend will go up.- Several pockets where GFS should outgrow (Auto, DC, SiPho, Power) driven by differentiated technology suite, customer partnerships, and need to have US footprint.

- Specific pockets of traction - DC, transition to optics, Low Earth Orbiting Satellites (Starlink)- China foundry doesn't compete with GFS as much as many believe, non-China demand not threatened but customers are selling into increasingly growing China market.

- Key takeaway was reacceleration in the Broadband business continues to look like a 2026 story but nothing to suggest slowdown with Charter despite major deal with Cox Communications.- Charter dipped below \(10\%\) of revenue in 2Q25, likely driven by combination of inventory builds and timing issues but reaffirmed on their most recent earnings call Step 2 of DAA deployment underway.- Akamai should be meaningful opportunity for SaaS growth in 2H25 with contribution starting in 3Q after integration began 9 months prior. Business runs on the Akamai cloud as they work to transition away from legacy CDN.- Trends in the Rest of the World business continue to help diversify away from customer concentration issues with major wins in Latin America and plenty of runway for growth internationally.

- Xiaomi renewal is coming up for renewal, last deal signed in 2021, accounts for approximately 170M devices with the last deal \(\sim\) \(60M\). Samsung/Apple are higher tier but closer to \(0.60 / \text{phone}\).- For CE/IoT TVs are a 200M unit opportunity and about 70M are currently under license. Large opportunity in connected cars.- Disney outcome is an important indicator for Streaming opportunity. Sets the precedent on pricing for the rest of the streaming market. SVoD and AVoD both strong opportunities.

- EML capacity is tight as demand has significantly outpaced expectations. 100G is very tight but 200G uses the same tools so will prioritize 200G ahead of 100G if necessary.- Ramping capacity by upgrading 3 inch fabs to 4inch, too many technology hurdles with 6 inch.- 200G pricing very strong – just LITE and AVGO which allows for taking price. Lot of moving pieces to consider on how best to raise pricing.- EML will take the lions share if using optical switching. EML has better reliability and sign integrity vs. CW allowing for longer distances.- Long term want to supply CW as well but that is being pushed to the right. Mostly trying to avoid being boxed out of the CW market so setting aside some modest capacity to be involved – remaining predominantly EML.- OCS expected to reach \(100M per quarter by 4CQ26 with large ramp into Q3 and even larger into Q4. Google is not EOL their own OCS but may use outside sources when certain specs are needed.- ASPs for 1.6T materially higher vs 800G and could even double.
- Etch and Deposition intensity continues to rise with packaging and 3D structures.

- China expected to be higher in Q3 but come down into Q4, share remains strong there given Chinese localization happening largely in non-critical steps.- 2026 remains strong for leading edge logic. Revenue continues to be tied to shipment timing and less due to any fundamental issues with ramping.

- Continuing work to reduce channel inventory in the Industrial & Auto business but expect they will be down to target levels by the end of the year.- Prior peak for I&A was \(115M and see a path to get back to that by end of next year. Still some overhang and still under-shipping true demand.- Company has made considerable progress in DC by driving higher unit attack rates. In addition to content/unit gains, LSCC noticing ASP uplift in AI Server with ASP likely rising faster than content/unit.- Higher end servers requiring multiple Secure Control Modules with additional opportunity in Add-In cards, storage cards, GPU cards, Network cards and others.

- Backlog has stabilized, month of July bookings was the highest for an individual month in 3 years (Book to Bill over 1).- \(\) 77M\(in inventory write offs steps down to maybe\) \ \(15 - 20M\) in Q3 (5% of GM benefit). Under utilization will take longer to go away but will start to ramp production in Q4 (can get back to prior peak revenue levels with reduced fab footprint).- LT gross margin target remains 65% (56% in Q3, 66.3% in Q2 excluding underutilization and inventory reserve charges)- Pricing is stable on existing businesses, cost structure increased on the upcycle because added capacity. Currently leading with newest products at competitive prices.- 65-70% of testing is done in house. Some of the more advanced packaging like those going into FPGA or DC product are done out of house and some sub-contractors are at full capacity right now (not a LT issue, some of that will clear on the consumer electronic side).

- Noted interest in ACCs from all hyperscalers with designs all 200G/lane where ACCs reach 2.5-4 meters.- Interest in LPO from both hyperscalers and "box" guys (switch, server). First option will be NIC-TOR, with first customer switch client (who also sells cables) selling into China cloud company. Other opportunities with NA hyperscalers.- Data Center opportunity in Photodiodes starting in 2H25. Management believes MTSI PDs on par with leading competitor offers share gain opportunity.- SATCOM opportunity tied to LEO satellite launches with signed opportunity of \(\) 50M\(over 2 years plus potential for\) \ \(25M\) incremental.- CPO may present a challenge at some point down the road but still need lasers, TIAs, and PDs, just in a different format.

- Don't see the lumpiness others are seeing in GAA, relatively even ramp. Samsung presenting some upside now.- Lead times are about 3-4 months for non-Chinese customers and about 6 months for Chinese customers so can see that China is not falling off.- Rapidus already starting purchasing in 2Q with 2Q being the heaviest weighting of Rapidus.- The makeup of the \(\) 500M\(cumulative GAA revenue has moved around but still feel confident in the ability to get there. 2026 still expected to be bigger than 2025- China revenue still focused largely on 28nm, selling tools from 2/3 generations ago. Local ecosystem investing but still not seeing local replacements in the field.

- Tier 1s in NA and EU inventory back to a good place so NXPI can get back to shipping to end demand. Noted one Tier 1 inventory likely at 2-4 weeks with NXPI suggesting should be much higher at 10-12 weeks. Aggregate across Tier 1s not disclosed but well below.- Escalation trends have gone up past 2 quarters suggesting market improving and also seeing signs of shortages.- Industrial business starting to look better in EU after seeing signs of recovery in NA earlier in the year.- Strength in China tied to wide adoption of S32 products. Also seeing strength in Korea and EU at slightly slower paces.- Consolidation of legacy 200mm fabs will take 9-10 years in total. Inventory build in 2H25 tied to "bridge stock" for customers of existing facility set to be shut down.

- CoWoS L share loss largely because yields were worse with additional steps on CMP layer requiring sub-micron resolution to find defects. Roadmap changed quickly and KLAC was already there with front end tool.- The new tool is significantly higher resolution, TSMC is pushing on the timeline, likely a faster qualification process of 3-6 months. The new tool is higher gross margin.- HBM4 uses all the same tools as HBM3E, no significant difference in capital intensity.- Large increase in Q4 CoWoS orders came most likely from CoWoS S.- Still working through engineering challenges with Echoscan.

- Apparel continuing to move along with new ramps at Old Navy and Academy Sports.- Phase 2 at Walmart may push into next year. Little visibility into timing and categories for phase 3 but still strong engagement with the customer.- Significant engagement on the food side with Kroger ramping and a pre-pilot with another Grocer (we expect Mercadona).- QCOM new chipset is RFID enabled, potentially pulling in some of the longer term opportunity.- Guidance for Q3 does not include an assumption for any turns business, seasonality for Q4 is up significantly in readers and down 5-10% on endpoint ICs. Q2 did not include pull ins.

- SOCAMM interest to use LPDDR vs. DDR but technologically difficult. SOCAMM does not have an RCD but could potentially have some other content.- MRDIMMs still expected to start in 2H26 with more significant ramp in 2027. Can be significantly more content with outsized share capture possible due to the likelihood of technological challenges related to mixing and matching components.- CXL continues to be pushed out, unlikely to contribute meaningfully soon.- Don't see any signs of pull-ins from customers or further downstream.

- Management remains confident pricing likely to be up in 4Q25 given supply/demand dynamics but meaningful eSSD opportunity unlikely until 2H26- HBF specifically designed for inference at both edge/DC and sample with controller will be ready in 1H27.- eSSD is mostly sold as a module with own controller while wafer solely sold into Android Market and SSD Module players.- Expecting 5% under supplied market in 2H25.- Seeing healthy inventory in both SNDK/Channel. Normal level in mobile with PC leaning to normalization.

- Goal is to find niches like Power Semi, SiC, GaN and to be a sustainable DD grower- Mixel - limited distribution/sales so they were delighted to join the company- Have great products but now they have SVCO global distribution/sales (can sell into China now)- TechX - Strong existing franchise, technical capability, and roadmap- Helps to increase TCAD and FTCO capabilities- Also in a new market which doesn't have entrenched competitors so can lock in customers early- China remains an important part of the business but seeing slowdown in Auto- Limited potential for M&A going forward as low on cash in the NT.

- Seeing competition in China at the high end in concentrated verticals like Radar and precision converters as China vendors make big push for Autos and Robotics.- Pricing less about inflationary pressures and more about making adjustments on product by product basis. Reiterated expectations for LSD price declines in normal case. China likely to be above the average but not by much.- Unlikely to gain much share on pricing given customers are sticky and don't want to redesign working solutions.- Large customers best prepared to handle impact from tariffs.- Expected GM benefit from 6 inch wafer fabs coming off this year. L Fab mostly empty today and will be shut down fully by the end of this year.

Explanation of Jefferies RatingsBuy - Describes securities that we expect to provide a total return (price appreciation plus yield) of 15% or more within a 12- month period. Hold - Describes securities that we expect to provide a total return (price appreciation plus yield) of plus 15% or minus 10% within a 12- month period.
Underperform - Describes securities that we expect to provide a total return (price appreciation plus yield) of minus \(10\%\) or less within a 12-month period.

The expected total return (price appreciation plus yield) for Buy rated securities with an average security price consistently below \(\) 10\(is 20\%\) or more within a 12- month period as these companies are typically more volatile than the overall stock market. For Hold rated securities with an average security price consistently below\) \ \(10\) , the expected total return (price appreciation plus yield) is plus or minus \(20\%\) within a 12- month period. For Underperform rated securities with an average security price consistently below \(\) 10\(, the expected total return (price appreciation plus yield) is minus\) 20\% \(or less within a 12- month period.
NR - The investment rating and price target have been temporarily suspended. Such suspensions are in compliance with applicable regulations and/or Jefferies policies.
CS - Coverage Suspended. Jefferies has suspended coverage of this company.
NC - Not covered. Jefferies does not cover this company.

Restricted - Describes issuers where, in conjunction with Jefferies engagement in certain transactions, company policy or applicable securities regulations prohibit certain types of communications, including investment recommendations.
Monitor - Describes securities whose company fundamentals and financials are being monitored, and for which no financial projections or opinions on the investment merits of the company are provided.

Jefferies' methodology for assigning ratings may include the following: market capitalization, maturity, growth/value, volatility and expected total return over the next 12 months. The price targets are based on several methodologies, which may include, but are not restricted to, analyses of market risk, growth rate, revenue stream, discounted cash flow (DCF), EBITDA, EPS, cash flow (CF), free cash flow (FCF), EV/EBITDA, P/E, PE/growth, P/CF, P/FCF, premium (discount)/average group EV/EBITDA, premium (discount)/average group P/E, sum of the parts, net asset value, dividend returns, and return on equity (ROE) over the next 12 months.

Jefferies Franchise Picks include stock selections from among the best stock ideas from our equity analysts over a 12 month period. Stock selection is based on fundamental analysis and may take into account other factors such as analyst conviction, differentiated analysis, a favorable risk/reward ratio and investment themes that Jefferies analysts are recommending. Jefferies Franchise Picks will include only Buy rated stocks and the number can vary depending on analyst recommendations for inclusion. Stocks will be added as new opportunities arise and removed when the reason for inclusion changes, the stock has met its desired return, if it is no longer rated Buy and/or if it triggers a stop loss. Stocks having 120 day volatility in the bottom quartile of S&P stocks will continue to have a \(15\%\) stop loss, and the remainder will have a \(20\%\) stop. Franchise Picks are not intended to represent a recommended portfolio of stocks and is not sector based, but we may note where we believe a Pick falls within an investment style such as growth or value.
